\#\#\# User: When I encounter Feynman diagram with loops, I have momentum integrals of the form:

$$ \\int d^{4}k\\ k^{D\-4}$$

And apparently it can be shown that it is equivalent to an integral of the form:

$$ \\int dk\\ k^{D\-1}$$

But I don't really understand that step. Is it by using some type of hyperspheric coordinates ?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Its a relativistic non\-Euclidean variant on hyperspheres, yes. Working in polar coordinates, $d^4k\=k^3dkd\\Omega$, where $\\int d\\Omega$ just multiplies things by a constant because all functions are of the polar coordinate $k$ only, so are angle\-independent. Thus $\\int d^4kf\\left( k\\right)\\propto\\int dkk^3f\\left( k\\right)$.

0.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In quantum field theory, when evaluating Feynman diagrams with loops, we often encounter momentum integrals. Consider the following integral transformation:

∫ d⁴k k^(D-4) → ∫ dk k^(D-1)

Which of the following statements best explains this transformation?

A) The transformation is a result of applying the residue theorem in complex analysis.
B) It's a consequence of using hyperspherical coordinates in 4-dimensional Minkowski space.
C) The transformation is derived from the Fourier transform of the propagator.
D) It's obtained by applying the Wick rotation to convert the integral to Euclidean space.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The transformation from ∫ d⁴k k^(D-4) to ∫ dk k^(D-1) is indeed a result of using a relativistic non-Euclidean variant of hyperspherical coordinates in 4-dimensional Minkowski space. In these coordinates, the volume element can be written as d⁴k = k³ dk dΩ, where dΩ represents the solid angle element. Since the integrand only depends on the magnitude of k, the angular integration ∫ dΩ contributes only a constant factor. This leaves us with an integral over k, where the measure d⁴k contributes a factor of k³, resulting in the form ∫ dk k^(D-1). This approach maintains the Lorentz invariance of the integral while simplifying its evaluation.

\#\#\# User: USB\-3, Thunder Bolt is today's standard, but I'm seeing a lot of boards still coming with a Parallel port on new motherboards with the LGA1151 socket.

Is the parallel port still in use for today's technology? 

I am not talking about the serial port, but the 25\-pin parallel port.

Some Examples
**Asus H110M\-D** and the **Gigabyte GA\-H110M\-S2PH**

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: First of all, if you're Asus, Gigabyte, etc. and you're designing a motherboard, the cost of adding a parallel port is practically non\-existent if you're already putting a serial port on it. Serial ports are still useful \-\- much more so than parallel ports. But the thing is, the SAME chip controls both, so the question becomes "why not?" Both of the motherboards you linked to also have a serial port on them.

Secondly, a USB\<\-\>Parallel adapter takes the simplest of interfaces and makes it way more complicated than it should be. Any time I encounter one of these adapters, I wind up spending more time getting the stupid adapter to work than I do getting the device that plugs into it to work. Sometimes there's just no substitute for having an actual, physical parallel port.

There are several other reasons why the good old parallel port can still be found on modern computers. I myself have witnessed the following with my own two eyes:

* [Software protection dongles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_protection_dongle). There are still many old and esoteric scientific/engineering applications in use that use the parallel port for their anti\-piracy dongles. One I saw recently was for calculating mineral densities from the sample data taken from a gas spectrometer. No need to update an app like that because all it does is a single, very specific kind of math problem. It does, however, benefit from running on a faster computer than the ones available when it was written, and the dongle lets you replace the computer with ease.
* Heavy industrial equipment interfaces. Think computerized textile looms, assembly line robots, parcel sorting machines, etc. These devices have a service life of decades \-\- much longer than the computer that controls them could be expected to last. Many of them have been in use since the 1980's when parallel ports were not only common; they were the fastest connection available at the time. I recently saw one being used by a plasma cutter making custom ducting for an HVAC supplier.
* My son is in the Boy Scouts. At their annual Pinewood Derby races, his troop has a track that records the race times over a parallel port and flags the winner from each round.
* Old large format/high\-capacity printers. Some of these things are 20 years old and still going strong. They even still make parts for them.
* Some business are still using old Nortel PBX systems for their phones. In the one I saw a couple years ago, a parallel port connected the PBX to the voice mail server. It also used a WYSE dumb terminal to program it, which I was unable to figure out.

These are just the ones I've seen. Remember that computers aren't just for playing games and goofing around on the Internet. Some of them are built to get work done, and parallel ports often come in handy for that.

1.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following statements best explains why parallel ports are still included on some modern motherboards despite the prevalence of newer technologies like USB-3 and Thunderbolt?

A) Parallel ports are faster and more reliable than USB-3 and Thunderbolt for data transfer.

B) The cost of including a parallel port is negligible when a serial port is already present, and it maintains compatibility with certain legacy hardware and software.

C) Parallel ports are required for modern gaming peripherals and high-speed internet connections.

D) Motherboard manufacturers include parallel ports purely for aesthetic reasons to appeal to nostalgic consumers.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B because the documentation explains that the cost of adding a parallel port is minimal when a serial port is already included, as they often use the same chip. Additionally, parallel ports maintain compatibility with various legacy systems and specialized equipment still in use, such as software protection dongles, industrial equipment interfaces, and old large format printers. Options A, C, and D are incorrect as they misrepresent the capabilities and reasons for including parallel ports on modern motherboards.

\#\#\# User: I have a list of filenames as `id-datetime.txt`, one each line, where id is always the same and datetime is ordered.

I need first and last datetime so having a sed\_script in a variable `$script` that grabs it I can do

```
sed -nr "1 $script p; \$ $script'

```

I get

```
datetime (oldest)
datetime (newest)

```

also working with a single\-file list.

Now what if I'd like to get also another line with also the id like

```
id
datetime (oldest)
datetime (newest)

```

is there an (easy) way of editing line 1 twice so it gives 2 separate lines?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Ok, I got it

```
1 {
    #hold the line
    h
    #extract id
    s|^([0-9]{6}).*|\1|; p
    #put line back again
    g
    #get datetime
    $sed_str
}

```

this part of the sed script will print (and edit) the first line twice

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: You have a list of filenames in the format "id-datetime.txt", one per line, where the id is consistent and the datetime is ordered. You want to extract the id, oldest datetime, and newest datetime. Which sed script will correctly achieve this output?

A) sed -nr "1 {h; s|^([0-9]{6}).*|\1|; p; g; $sed_str}; $ $sed_str"

B) sed -nr "1 {h; s|^([0-9]{6}).*|\1|; p; g; $sed_str; p}; $ $sed_str"

C) sed -nr "1 {h; s|^([0-9]{6}).*|\1|; p; g; $sed_str}; $ $sed_str; p"

D) sed -nr "1 {h; s|^([0-9]{6}).*|\1|; p; g; $sed_str}; $ {$sed_str; p}"

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
Option B is the correct answer because it processes the first line twice to extract both the id and the oldest datetime, and then processes the last line to get the newest datetime. Here's a breakdown of the script:

1. `1 {...}` applies the commands in braces to the first line.
2. `h` holds the original line in the hold space.
3. `s|^([0-9]{6}).*|\1|` extracts the id (assumed to be 6 digits).
4. `p` prints the extracted id.
5. `g` retrieves the original line from the hold space.
6. `$sed_str` applies the datetime extraction (not shown in the snippet).
7. `p` prints the extracted oldest datetime.
8. `$ $sed_str` applies the datetime extraction to the last line.

Option A is incorrect because it doesn't print the oldest datetime. Option C is incorrect because it prints an extra line at the end. Option D is incorrect because it doesn't print the oldest datetime from the first line.

\#\#\# User: I used SimpleTeX4ht to convert a LaTeX file to HTML. The file is fine except that square roots are rendering badly in juxtaposition with the rest of the text, e.g. like: ![like this](https://i.stack.imgur.com/KzFgZ.png) Any suggestions on how to get the square roots to render better? (Whether by using a different converter, using different LaTeX, etc.) My LaTeX code is ``` \noindent \textbf{Example:} Failure of unique prime factorization in $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}\hspace{0.1 cm}]$:\\ $6 = (1 + \sqrt{-5})\cdot (1 + \sqrt{-5}) = 2 \cdot 3$.\ ``` and the corresponding HTML is something like ```html

Example: Failure of unique prime factorization in ℤ[ ]:
6 = (1 + ) ⋅ (1 + ) = 2 ⋅ 3.
``` \- \#\#\# Top Answer: The previous two answers have already addressed your immediate query. However, I would like to add that may be you should try `pandoc`[Homepage](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/). It can convert various formats like `latex`, html, xhtml, html5, docx, odt, epub, `conTeXt` etc. into each other. My experience has been pleasant. However, installation of pandoc requires `haskell platform` which took nearly 350MB of space on `ubuntu 12.04`. For a good rendering of math in `html`, I think that `mathjax` is the way to go. It is supported by most browsers. It can handle most of the `latex` math environments. One drawback though is the slow loading of the webpages with a lot of math. I used: ``` pandoc -s --mathjax a.tex -o a.html ``` to get ![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/LKoYY.png) Personally, I have converted my PhD Thesis with a lot of math into html using `pandoc` which also handles bibliographies. EDIT: Major bugs regarding math environments have been addressed in pandoc v1\.9\.2\. The example above uses the latest version 1\.9\.4\.5\. Ubuntu repository has older versions. Hence, it is recommended that the latest versions be installed from `haskell` repository for best results.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A LaTeX user is trying to convert their document to HTML and is experiencing issues with square root rendering. Which of the following approaches would be the most comprehensive solution to address this problem and potentially improve overall document conversion?

A) Modify the LaTeX code to use a different square root notation
B) Use SimpleTeX4ht with custom CSS styling for square root elements
C) Convert the document using Pandoc with MathJax support
D) Manually edit the HTML output to adjust the square root images

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the most comprehensive solution for several reasons:

1. Pandoc is a versatile document converter that can handle various formats, including LaTeX to HTML conversion.
2. Using the command "pandoc -s --mathjax a.tex -o a.html" enables MathJax support, which is specifically designed to render mathematical notation in web browsers.
3. MathJax can handle most LaTeX math environments, providing better rendering for complex mathematical expressions, including square roots.
4. This approach doesn't require modifying the original LaTeX code or manually editing the output HTML.
5. While MathJax may lead to slower page loading for content with extensive mathematical notation, it offers the best balance of quality and ease of use for mathematical content on the web.

Options A and B might offer partial solutions but would require more effort and may not address all potential rendering issues. Option D is time-consuming and not scalable for large documents.

\#\#\# User: When we measure an electrical quantity on Digital multimeter (DMM) like current, if we dont get readings of small range scale we switch the range utill we get our reading, same goes for voltage. But what is the quantity for which we do not change the scale on DMM and why? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Also, what is the use of defining a voltage reference point?

All voltages are relative, a concept which a lot of people have trouble understanding. 

It is rather common to say that "at Point A we have X Volts" but actually it is wrong!

Officially you should say "Between point B and point A we have X volts".  

As that become tedious it is easier (common) to define a reference point. Then if you say "at Point A we have X Volts" your are actually saying "Between the reference point and point A we have X volts".

The next step often used in a schematic when defining the reference point is to use the ground symbol for that.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An electrical engineer is designing a circuit and needs to measure various voltages. Which of the following statements best describes the concept of voltage measurement and reference points?

A) Voltage can be accurately measured at a single point without any reference.
B) Voltage measurements always require changing the multimeter scale for each reading.
C) Voltage is always measured between two points, with one typically serving as a reference.
D) The ground symbol in a schematic has no relation to voltage measurements.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
The correct answer is C. Voltage is always a relative measurement between two points. When we say "at Point A we have X Volts," we're implicitly referring to the voltage difference between Point A and a reference point, often ground. This concept is fundamental in electrical engineering and circuit design.

Option A is incorrect because voltage cannot be measured at a single point without a reference. It's always a potential difference between two points.

Option B is false because while we may need to change scales for current or some voltage measurements, it's not always necessary for every reading.

Option D is incorrect because the ground symbol in a schematic is often used to denote the reference point for voltage measurements.

This question tests understanding of voltage measurement principles, the importance of reference points, and common practices in circuit design and analysis.

\#\#\# User: Recently, we've been getting a lot of new users who don't know the Stack Exchange way and provide answers to questions that are little more than anecdotes about a similar situation. These frequently end up being deleted since they don't add any value to the Q\&A. 

Some, however, have the grain of a proper answer in them, and with a little more detail in them, could be useful to the OP and future readers. Now, moderators can add notices to a post that needs some TLC. The two most commonly used on this site are "insufficient explanation":

> We're looking for long answers that provide some explanation and context. Don't just give a one\-line answer; explain why your answer is right, ideally with citations. Answers that don't include explanations may be removed.

and "citation needed":

> This post does not cite any references or sources. Please help improve this post by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.

However, neither of these really address the types of posts that we're getting. "Insufficient explanation" doesn't work for a 500\-word rant about roofing contractors (for example), and "citation needed" doesn't sound right asking for a link to some product, or a description of a technique.

Over on [Pets Stack Exchange](https://pets.stackexchange.com/), they get a lot of anecdotal answers too, so they [asked for and received a custom post notice](https://pets.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/1844/custom-post-notice-request) to specifically address these kinds of answers:

> Thank you for sharing your experience! Pets Stack Exchange answers require more context than an interesting anecdote alone can provide; this story\-based answer really needs some authoritative references to support it. Please add links to help support the experience you're describing, or this answer might eventually be removed.

Should we ask for a new post notice for these answers, and if so, how should it be worded?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I agree we can use something. Here's my first attempt at a custom notice, but maybe someone can do a little better job with the wording. Our goal is to guide users in the right direction, be informative and cautionary, without scaring them away, and I'm not sure I did that.

> Stack Exchange is a Q\&A format site where we are looking for answers
>  that help resolve the question. Story and anecdote based answers work
>  better in forums and and may be deleted here since they do not fit
>  well in our format. Please help improve this post by rewording it to
>  focus on the steps needed to resolve the question.

These answers often don't meet the Stack Exchange standard for valuable Q&A content. This notice aims to educate new users about the Stack Exchange format while encouraging them to enhance their contributions without discouraging participation.

\#\#\# User: I have a standard apache error log file. I would like to see what URLs are causing 404s, since I have moved this site around and I want to find bad links. Can anyone recommend a bash snippet that will parse this log using awk or something to show me the popular 404s?

I know there are advanced programmes for this sort of thing. I'm just looking for something simple.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This should do it:

```
grep ' 404 ' /var/log/apache2/access.log | cut -d ' ' -f 7 |sort |uniq -c |sort -n

```

7.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are a system administrator managing an Apache web server. You need to analyze the access log to identify the most frequent URLs causing 404 errors. Which of the following command pipelines would correctly accomplish this task?

A) grep '404' /var/log/apache2/access.log | awk '{print $7}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn

B) grep ' 404 ' /var/log/apache2/access.log | cut -d ' ' -f 7 | sort | uniq -c | sort -n

C) awk '/404/' /var/log/apache2/access.log | cut -d ' ' -f 7 | uniq | sort -n

D) sed -n '/404/p' /var/log/apache2/access.log | cut -d ' ' -f 7 | sort | uniq

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
A) This is close, but uses awk instead of cut and sorts in reverse numerical order (-rn), which would show the most frequent 404s first.
B) This is the correct answer, matching the provided solution. It greps for 404 errors, extracts the URL (7th field), sorts, counts unique occurrences, and sorts numerically.
C) This uses awk instead of grep, doesn't count occurrences (missing uniq -c), and doesn't sort by frequency.
D) This uses sed instead of grep, doesn't count occurrences, and doesn't sort by frequency.

The correct answer (B) properly extracts, sorts, counts, and orders the 404 error URLs from the Apache access log.

> **MAMESZ**

and

or

> **MAMESZ's** and **police's**

\#\#\# Top Answer: * It's not a genitive, its a clitic.\*

The spelling is certainly "police's", \[po'li:siz]. Probably "Mamesz's" \[mamesiz] is prefered by most writers, but there is some variation. For example 

> Alexis **Sanchez's** struggles reveal Manchester United's main problem in attack under Jose Mourinho [source](https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/manchester-united-sevilla-alexis-sanchez-champions-league-a8255536.html)

For the police, consider rewording using "of": Instead of saying "The police's role has changed." say "The role of the police has changed".

\#\#\# User: Active\-low reset inputs seem to be a holdover from TTL logic where the falling edge was faster than the rising edge, so the falling edge was decided as more important to increase the maximum possible frequency. 

I'm not so sure how relevant that is with modern CMOS but it's still very easy to find chips that are active low reset (my circuit board design, which uses some old\-school 74XX chips, all have active low reset. Even the Microcontroller is active low reset). I'm guessing there's reasons beyond the technology used as to why this still pervades (such as active low would reset on a brown out condition, chips would reset on power\-on, tradition, etc.). 

Something that I haven't really thought about until now, is what would be the better design when driving active low logic (specifically resets on other chips) from a microcontroller. Is it better to: 

A. Drive the resets directly from the microcontroller, with a 1 for an indefinite period of time, or

B. Add a pullup resistor to Vdd and use the microcontroller to briefly pull down to 0

Option B adds more footprint and cost (BOM), but I would guess it would be more stable, since it's passively being tied up to the non\-reset position, and uses less static power consumption (even if negligible) on the uC since the output would be high for only a brief blip. Also trivial, but the programming would also be a little easier (Reset \= 1 resets the line). Option A is simpler but, but an unintended reset on that line would cause the system to fail. A full power cycle would be needed to recover the system.

I also think about what position I would like to be in better with my design if the reset line also were to fail permanently \-\- if it were pulled up by a resistor, the system could still remain mostly functional, but if it was just the microcontroller driving the output, everything would be stuck in reset (completely nonfunctional). I've never heard of a single pin failing on a microcontroller though. 

For an active low *data* line, I would never consider option B. There's no justification to add that many pullups. 

I'm guessing there's no practical difference between the two (i.e., microcontrollers are reliable enough to drive a solid 1 for long periods of time without glitches), so I should go with A to save on cost and footprint. Is either option clearly better? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Essentially, either works; A is probably better, B is more flexible.

A will drive the reset line to '1' faster, which could be an issue on a very large board.

B allows the option of adding other means of driving reset \- hidden switch \+ paperclip, brownout monitor, watchdog timer, etc. It probably doesn't even cost the board space for a resistor, because a lot of microcontrollers have software configurable pullup resistors on each pin.

10.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In designing a circuit with active-low reset inputs, which approach is generally considered the most flexible and allows for additional reset mechanisms?

A) Directly driving the reset line from the microcontroller with a constant logic 1
B) Using a pull-up resistor to Vdd and briefly pulling down to 0 with the microcontroller
C) Implementing active-high reset inputs instead of active-low
D) Connecting the reset line directly to Vdd without microcontroller control

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Option B, using a pull-up resistor to Vdd and briefly pulling down to 0 with the microcontroller, is considered the most flexible approach. While both options A and B can work, B allows for the addition of other reset mechanisms such as hidden switches, brownout monitors, or watchdog timers. This flexibility can be achieved without significant additional cost or board space, especially if the microcontroller has software-configurable pull-up resistors. Option A, while simpler, doesn't offer this flexibility. Options C and D are not recommended practices for systems using active-low reset inputs.

\#\#\# Top Answer: It's not really clear what you want.

grep -E "^User name:\s*[A-Za-z ]+$" text.txt

If you want only the name, we can enhance the command with sed:

grep -E "^User name:\s*[A-Za-z ]+$" text.txt | sed -e '1,$s/^User name:\s*\([A-Za-z ]*\)$/\1/'

\#\#\# Top Answer:

You can use below query

DELETE FROM `url_rewrite` where entity_type='product'

and run the below command.

php bin/magento ok:urlrewrites:regenerate --entity-type=product

```

Question: A Magento 2 e-commerce site is experiencing inconsistent product URL formats. Some products have URLs like "http://www.test.com/product-url-key" while others show as "http://www.test.com/catalog/product/view/id/2221/product-url-key". \#\#\# User: I'm using ansible in a vagrant environment managing a debian box. Due multiple ansible provisioners with vault encrypted data (e. g. database root password) I have to enter the vault password once by the first provisioner. Currently this password is stored in `/tmp`, read by script in every ansible provisioner and overwritten with `/dev/null` and then deleted by the last provisioner.

Ansible is able to call a script which returns the vault password. So this script will run in a separate shell.

If an attacker managed to break into the VM he has the opportunity to recover any temporary file and to get in possesion of the vault password.

While these vagrant environments will be used in production I'm looking for a more secure approach. What first came into my mind is to read and write into memory somehow. So a VM reboot would wipe the memory. I know the mentioned data could somehow be swapped on disk. But I think it's more difficult to get this data than the temporary file approach.

**Edit**

I forgot to mention the security risk if a provisioner fails. Then the last provisioner will not be executed and the temporary file remains on the file system.

---

I provided an additional answere showing the integrated solution just for anyone interested in the solution of the origin problem that led to this question.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
```
$ awk '/^Members/ { for (i=2; i<=NF; ++i) { sub(",$", "", $i); print $i } }' file
admin
Admin1
John
sam
dean

```

This uses `awk` to look for any line that starts with the string `Members`. When such a line is found, it iterates over the whitespace\-delimited fields of that line, from the second field onwards. Each field has its trailing comma removed (if one exists) before it's printed on its own line.

Redirect the output to a new file if you wish to save it, using

```
awk ...as above... file >newfile

```

---

Using `sed`:

```
$ sed -n '/^Members[[:blank:]]*/{ s///; s/,[[:blank:]]*/,/g; y/,/\n/; p; }' file
admin
Admin1
John
sam
dean

```

This locates the lines starting with the string `Members` and then deletes this string and any blanks (tabs or spaces) following it. It then removes the blanks after any comma in the remainder of the line and changes the commas into newlines before printing the resulting list.

With GNU `sed`, you could combine

```
s/,[[:blank:]]*/,/g; y/,/\n/; p;

```

into

```
s/,[[:blank:]]*/\n/gp;

```

13.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: You need to extract a list of member names from a file where they are listed on a single line starting with "Members:" and separated by commas. Which of the following commands will correctly extract these names, each on a separate line, while also removing any trailing commas and leading/trailing whitespace?

A) awk '/^Members/ { print $2, $3, $4, $5 }' file

B) sed -n '/^Members/{ s/^Members://; s/,/\n/g; p }' file

C) awk '/^Members/ { for (i=2; i<=NF; ++i) { sub(",$", "", $i); print $i } }' file

D) grep "^Members" file | tr ',' '\n' | sed 's/^Members://'

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the correct answer because it:
1. Correctly identifies lines starting with "Members"
2. Iterates through all fields after "Members:"
3. Removes trailing commas from each field
4. Prints each member name on a separate line
5. Handles cases where there might be varying numbers of members

Option A fails because it only prints a fixed number of fields and doesn't remove commas.
Option B is close but doesn't handle potential spaces after commas and before names.
Option D doesn't remove trailing commas and may include "Members:" in the output if it's not separated from the first name by a comma.

\#\#\# User: Sorry if this question comes across a little basic.

I am looking to use LASSO variable selection for a multiple linear regression model in R. I have 15 predictors, one of which is categorical(will that cause a problem?). After setting my $x$ and $y$ I use the following commands:

```r
model = lars(x, y)
coef(model)

```

My problem is when I use `coef(model)`. This returns a matrix with 15 rows, with one extra predictor added each time. However there is no suggestion as to which model to choose. Have I missed something? Is there a way I can get the lars package to return just one "*best*" model?

There are other posts suggesting using `glmnet` instead but this seems more complicated. An attempt is as follows, using the same $x$ and $y$. Have I missed something here?: 

```r
cv = cv.glmnet(x, y)
model = glmnet(x, y, type.gaussian="covariance", lambda=cv$lambda.min)
predict(model, type="coefficients")

```

The final command returns a list of my variables, the majority with a coefficient although some are \=0\. Is this the correct choice of the "*best*" model selected by LASSO? If I then fit a linear model with all my variables which had coefficients `not=0` I get very similar, but slightly different, coefficient estimates. Is there a reason for this difference? Would it be acceptable to refit the linear model with these variables chosen by LASSO and take that as my final model? Otherwise I cannot see any p\-values for significance. Have I missed anything? 

Does 

```
type.gaussian="covariance" 

```

ensure that that `glmnet` uses multiple linear regression?

Does the automatic normalisation of the variables affect the coefficients at all? Is there any way to include interaction terms in a LASSO procedure?

I am looking to use this procedure more as a demonstration of how LASSO can be used than for any model that will actually be used for any important inference/prediction if that changes anything.

Thank you for taking the time to read this. Any general comments on LASSO/lars/glmnet would also be greatly appreciated.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Using `glmnet` is really easy once you get the grasp of it thanks to its excellent vignette in [http://web.stanford.edu/\~hastie/glmnet/glmnet\_alpha.html](http://web.stanford.edu/~hastie/glmnet/glmnet_alpha.html) (you can also check the CRAN package page).
As for the best lambda for `glmnet`, the rule of thumb is to use 

```
cvfit <- glmnet::cv.glmnet(x, y)
coef(cvfit, s = "lambda.1se")

```

instead of `lambda.min`.

To do the same for `lars` you have to do it by hand. Here is my solution

```
cv <- lars::cv.lars(x, y, plot.it = FALSE, mode = "step")
idx <- which.max(cv$cv - cv$cv.error <= min(cv$cv))
coef(lars::lars(x, y))[idx,]

```

Bear in mind that this is not exactly the same, because this is stopping at a lasso knot (when a variable enters) instead of at any point.

Please note that `glmnet` is the preferred package now, it is actively maintained, more so than `lars`, and that there have been questions about `glmnet` vs `lars` answered before (algorithms used differ).

As for your question of using lasso to choose variables and then fit OLS, it is an ongoing debate. Google for OLS post Lasso and there are some papers discussing the topic. Even the authors of Elements of Statistical Learning admit it is possible. 

**Edit**: Here is the code to reproduce more accurately what `glmnet` does in `lars`

```
  cv <- lars::cv.lars(x, y, plot.it = FALSE)
  ideal_l1_ratio <- cv$index[which.max(cv$cv - cv$cv.error <= min(cv$cv))]
  obj <- lars::lars(x, y)
  scaled_coefs <- scale(obj$beta, FALSE, 1 / obj$normx)
  l1 <- apply(X = scaled_coefs, MARGIN = 1, FUN = function(x) sum(abs(x)))
  coef(obj)[which.max(l1 / tail(l1, 1) > ideal_l1_ratio),]

```

14.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In the context of LASSO variable selection using the glmnet package in R, which of the following statements is correct regarding the selection of the optimal lambda value?

A) The best lambda value is always lambda.min from cv.glmnet()
B) The rule of thumb is to use lambda.1se from cv.glmnet()
C) The optimal lambda should be manually calculated using the lars package
D) The lambda value doesn't affect the variable selection process

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to the documentation, the rule of thumb for selecting the best lambda value when using glmnet is to use "lambda.1se" from cv.glmnet(). This is illustrated in the code snippet:

```r
cvfit <- glmnet::cv.glmnet(x, y)
coef(cvfit, s = "lambda.1se")
```

Option A is incorrect because although lambda.min is available, it's not considered the rule of thumb. Option C is incorrect because while manual calculation using lars is possible, it's not the recommended method when using glmnet. Option D is incorrect because the lambda value is crucial in the LASSO variable selection process, determining the strength of the penalty and thus affecting which variables are selected.

\#\#\# User: Moving sufficiently far away from a light source one would not be able to measure a steady stream of light, but only single photons every now an then. The experience would be a very faint blinking.

Can this behavior be translated to gravity? From what I understand gravity is similarly quantized and transmitted via gravitons. How would one experience/measure gravity, sufficiently far away from every other body of mass? As a blinking of gravity? A tug of Planck\-force every now and then? What is the mental picture to paint here?

**Edit:**  

As an interested layman I deduced the necessity to quantize gravity by the necessity to quantize the attractive force it causes between objects (space and time are quantized, therefore acceleration must be, therefore force must be as well). I then further assumed, that these "quantum force packets" are equivalent to a graviton. The first couple of answers indicate, that this assumption is wrong.  

So, my rephrased question is: How would one experience/measure the force, induced by gravity, sufficiently far away from every other body of mass?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> From what I understand gravity is similarly quantized and transmitted via gravitons.

Well, we don't know that. There is no accepted quantum theory of gravity, only approximations like semiclassical approaches. We cannot give you a "mental picture" at the moment because we don't have one. We can speculate all day, and extrapolate from all the other forces and such, but we cannot, with the certainty usually required of scientific theories, proclaim anything definite about the way gravity works at the quantum scale.

16.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the StackExchange documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding our current understanding of quantum gravity?

A) Gravity is definitively quantized and transmitted via gravitons, similar to how light is transmitted via photons.

B) We have a complete and accepted quantum theory of gravity that explains how it behaves at the quantum scale.

C) Gravity cannot be quantized due to fundamental differences from other fundamental forces.

D) There is no widely accepted quantum theory of gravity, only approximations and speculative models.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. The StackExchange response clearly states that "There is no accepted quantum theory of gravity, only approximations like semiclassical approaches." It emphasizes that we cannot make definitive claims about how gravity works at the quantum scale due to lack of a complete theory. Options A and B are incorrect as they claim certainty about quantum gravity that we don't currently have. Option C is also incorrect, as it makes a definitive claim about the impossibility of quantizing gravity, which is not supported by the given information. \#\#\# User: [![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/n5LnP.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/n5LnP.jpg)

TLDR: The white wire is showing a current despite not being connected to power. Is that normal, and should I be concerned?

Long Version:
In the picture is a white 14/3 wire running parallel and very close to a black 14/2 wire. They travel closely for about 8 feet to the crawl space below.

The white one used to be jumped off of the black wire in the box above this picture (but out of frame), but It is now wired only to a 3\-way switch in that box. In the crawl space it is dead\-ended in a junction box.

I was going to use it to operate a different light that hadn't been on a 3\-way switch before by reconnecting it at that crawl\-space junction box.

However, it is showing a current despite no known connection to a circuit. Is it possible that running so close to the live black wire makes it look like it has a current? And is it safe to use it as is, or should I crack into the wall more to separate them?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Voltage and Current are 2 very different things. Voltage is like pressure in a water line, current is the flow rate. A tiny 1/4" at high pressure isn't going to flow a lot of water, a fire hydrant at relatively low pressure will flow A LOT!

Now, getting to your issue: You probably have an induced current , that's how transformers work. All you can do is put a load (like and old style incandescent bulb) on it and see if the power goes away. The non\-contact testers or even the modern multi\-meters are so sensitive they'll detect almost anything. If you don't feel safe working on the circuit, you'll have to turn off the breaker to the other cable as well.

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An electrician is troubleshooting a white wire that shows current despite not being connected to a power source. The wire runs parallel to a live black wire for about 8 feet. What is the most likely explanation for this phenomenon, and what should the electrician do to safely work on the circuit?

A) The white wire has a short circuit and needs to be replaced immediately.
B) The current reading is due to induced voltage from the nearby live wire. The electrician should use an incandescent bulb to test for actual power flow.
C) The non-contact tester is faulty and giving false readings. The electrician should replace the testing equipment.
D) The white wire is secretly connected to another power source. The electrician needs to trace the entire wire path to find the connection.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The most likely explanation is induced voltage, which occurs when a wire runs parallel to a live wire for some distance. This is similar to how transformers work. The electrician should use an incandescent bulb as a load to test if there's actual power flow in the wire. If there's no real current, the bulb won't light up. For safety, the electrician should turn off the breaker for both cables before working on the circuit, as sensitive modern testing equipment can detect even small induced voltages.

\#\#\# User: I am trying to replace the hard drive in an old MBP\-15 mid 2010 with a new SSD. The old disk is encrypted. I did that on my own two MBPs successfully, but both disks were not encrypted. The Mac is running OS X v10\.10\.5\.

I reboot the friends MBP with `CMD`\+`R` into Recovery Mode and run `Disk Utility` \-\> `Restore` with the old drive set as "source" and the new SSD set as "backup"

It runs for a few minutes, but then it fails with

```
RESTORE FAILURE
Could not restore - Device not configured

```

The SSD is brand new and connected to the Mac via USB.  

Does anyone have an idea what is going on?

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\- Solution \-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-

Thanks for the answers. The simple solution was to exchange the original HD with the still empty SSD and run restore in that combination. I believe it may have been some kind of USB problem, maybe related to the different read / write speeds (slow reading, encrypted disk vs super fast SSD write). Not sure, but it worked. Cheers!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The outcome you're seeing is probably a (security) feature, not a bug. I would think that Disk Utility would prompt for a password to enable access to the encrypted drive before allowing it to be read in order to perform the restore. Before attempting the restore use the Terminal command string "diskutil corestorage unlockVolume UUID \-stdinpassphrase" followed by the password to unlock the drive then see if your restore runs to completion.

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: When attempting to replace an encrypted hard drive with a new SSD in a MacBook Pro, what is the recommended first step before performing a restore using Disk Utility in Recovery Mode?

A) Exchange the original HD with the empty SSD and run restore
B) Use the Terminal command "diskutil corestorage unlockVolume UUID -stdinpassphrase" to unlock the encrypted drive
C) Format the new SSD to match the encryption of the original drive
D) Disable FileVault encryption on the original drive before starting the restore process

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. Before attempting to restore an encrypted drive to a new SSD, it's crucial to unlock the encrypted volume using the Terminal command "diskutil corestorage unlockVolume UUID -stdinpassphrase" followed by the password. This step allows Disk Utility to access the encrypted data on the original drive, which is necessary for a successful restore operation. 

Option A, while mentioned as a workaround in the solution, is not the recommended first step and may not work in all cases. 

Option C is incorrect because formatting the new SSD to match the encryption wouldn't solve the issue of accessing the data on the original encrypted drive. 

Option D is not advisable as it would compromise the data security and is unnecessary if the correct unlocking procedure is followed.

\#\#\# Top Answer: You mention using a script, so what about in the script utilizing the [`SetProduct`](http://help.arcgis.com/en/arcgisdesktop/10.0/help/index.html#//000v0000003w000000) function? If I understand it properly, you have to explicitly set the product (by importing it) *before* you import the arcpy module:

```
import arcinfo 
import arcpy

arcpy.env.workspace = "C:/Data"
arcpy.do_whatever_requires_arcinfo

```

Edit: I haven't tested this, but based on your comment below, how about checking for the availability of the ArcInfo license:

```
Python 2.6.5 (r265:79096, Mar 19 2010, 21:48:26) [MSC v.1500 32 bit (Intel)]
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

u'Available'
>>> arcpy.CheckProduct("ArcInfo")
u'Available'
>>> if arcpy.CheckProduct("ArcInfo") == "Available":
...     import arcinfo
... 

```

...and then if it's available, `import arcinfo` and do your task. You could perhaps incorporate Python's [`time.sleep`](http://docs.python.org/library/time.html) function to wait until you check again, assuming the license is still tied up.

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: You are developing a complex geoprocessing model that needs to run on multiple machines concurrently, but you have limited ArcGIS licenses. The model requires the ArcInfo license for a specific tool, but it's only needed for a short duration. Which of the following code snippets would be the most appropriate to dynamically check for and utilize the ArcInfo license within your Python script?

A) 
```python
import arcpy
arcpy.CheckProduct("ArcInfo")
import arcinfo
arcpy.do_whatever_requires_arcinfo()
```

B)
```python
import arcpy
if arcpy.CheckProduct("ArcInfo") == "Available":
    import arcinfo
    arcpy.do_whatever_requires_arcinfo()
else:
    time.sleep(300)  # Wait 5 minutes before checking again
```

C)
```python

```

D)
```python
import arcpy

arcpy.do_whatever_requires_arcinfo()
```

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Option B is the most appropriate solution for this scenario. It checks for the availability of the ArcInfo license using arcpy.CheckProduct("ArcInfo"). If the license is available, it imports arcinfo and executes the function requiring ArcInfo. If the license is not available, it waits for 5 minutes before checking again. This approach allows for dynamic license checking and efficient use of the limited ArcInfo license across multiple machines.

Option A is incorrect because it doesn't check for license availability before importing arcinfo.
Option C is incorrect because it assumes the ArcInfo license is always available and doesn't perform any checks.
Option D is incorrect because SetProduct is not the correct function for checking or setting the license dynamically.

How to turn off software updates?

\#\#\# Top Answer:  Fischer, there are two different types of software updates that occur on iOS; updates to the apps you have installed and updates to the operating system itself. 

 To disable app updates over your friend’s cellular connection, navigate to Settings → iTunes \& App Store and scroll to the very bottom. Tap the toggle next to “Use Cellular Data,” but keep in mind that this will also disable the use of iTunes Match and iTunes Radio over the phone’s cellular connection.

 If you are concerned about updates to iOS itself being installed over your friend’s cellular connection, don’t be — having contacted a friend of mine who is an Apple Genius, she tells me that your iPhone won’t install updates to your operating system without a connection to WiFi or the user’s specific permission.

 If your friend continues to have an issue, she may want to contact Apple about a potential bug.

20.answer:

Question: A user notices that "Software Updates" is consuming a significant amount of cellular data on their iPhone 6 running iOS 8.1.1, despite having seemingly disabled all relevant settings. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this situation?

A) The iPhone is downloading and installing iOS system updates over cellular data
B) There is a potential bug in the iOS software causing unintended data usage
C) The user hasn't properly disabled app updates in the iTunes & App Store settings
D) The cellular data usage statistics are inaccurate and not reflecting actual usage

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A) is incorrect because according to the information provided, iPhones won't install iOS system updates over cellular data without specific user permission.
B) is the most likely explanation. The answer suggests that if the issue persists after checking all settings, it could be due to a potential bug, and the user should contact Apple for support.
C) is unlikely because the screenshots show that the user has already disabled cellular data usage for the iTunes & App Store.
D) is possible but less likely than B, as resetting the statistics still showed data being used, indicating a persistent issue rather than a simple reporting error.

\#\#\# User: Suppose my system has Organizations which contain Departments which contain Work Areas, so it makes sense for me to query something like `get /organization/o1/department/d2/workarea/w3/employees` to get a list of employees in Work Area W3 that's part of Department D2 that's part of Organization O1\.

Let's further suppose that those numbering spaces are guaranteed separate and each item is unique, such that there is definitely no other Work Area W3 anywhere. The only Work Area W3 is clearly and uniquely part of Department D2\. And so on up the hierarchy.

Two questions:

* Is it good design to support a REST URL like `/organization/o1/department/d2/workarea/w3/employees` (because it fully represents the resource) or is it better support something more like `/workarea/w3/employees` (because it's guaranteed unique and the server knows what it's looking for)?
* In implementation, is it good design to support the "long" resource path but also make everything but the last element optional? E.g., `/[organization/o1/][department/d2/]workarea/w3/employees` with the optional bits in square brackets?

Curious about what is best practice, and why.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Is it good design to support a REST URL like /organization/o1/department/d2/workarea/w3/employees (because it fully represents the resource) or is it better support something more like /workarea/w3/employees (because it's guaranteed unique and the server knows what it's looking for)?

Those spellings are both *fine*.

The first spelling allows you to take advantage of dot segments and relative resources to identify another resource within the same path segment hierarchy (ex: ../w7/employees). The second spelling has the advantage of being succinct, and might be better when viewed in a browser history, or in an HTTP log, or when documenting....

---

> In implementation, is it good design to support the "long" resource path but also make everything but the last element optional? E.g., /\[organization/o1/]\[department/d2/]workarea/w3/employees with the optional bits in square brackets?

Maybe? Remember: to the world outside of your implementation

```
/organization/o1/department/d2/workarea/w3/employees
/workarea/w3/employees

```

these are two *different resources*, and will be treated that way. When requests target these resources, the responses will be cached differently, and invalidating the responses for one will leave stale copies of the other.

That doesn't mean that it's the wrong choice to make, just that supporting both has consequences. In some cases, you might instead have one resource redirect to the other, or have them share a representation using the Content\-Location header. There are different trade offs you might make depending on context.

But me: if I didn't have a compelling requirement for two resources, I would try to get by with just one.

21.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the StackExchange documentation:

Question: In designing a RESTful API for a system with hierarchical resources (Organization > Department > Work Area > Employees), which approach is considered best practice for URL structure and why?

A) Use only the longest, most specific path (e.g., /organization/o1/department/d2/workarea/w3/employees) to fully represent the resource hierarchy.

B) Use only the shortest, uniquely identifiable path (e.g., /workarea/w3/employees) for simplicity and efficiency.

C) Implement both long and short paths as separate resources, allowing clients to use either option freely.

D) Implement the long path with optional elements (e.g., /[organization/o1/][department/d2/]workarea/w3/employees), making intermediate elements optional but supporting the full hierarchy.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: While all options have their merits, option B is generally considered the best practice. Using the shortest, uniquely identifiable path (/workarea/w3/employees) offers several advantages:

1. Simplicity: It's easier to use, document, and maintain.
2. Efficiency: Shorter URLs are quicker to process and transmit.
3. Avoiding redundancy: If work areas are guaranteed to be unique, including the full hierarchy is unnecessary.
4. Caching benefits: Simpler URLs are more cache-friendly.

Option A, while comprehensive, can be overly verbose. Option C introduces complexity by treating two paths as different resources, which can lead to caching and consistency issues. Option D, while flexible, can introduce ambiguity and complexity in implementation and usage.

The key is to balance representational accuracy with practical concerns like simplicity and efficiency. In this case, since uniqueness is guaranteed at the work area level, the shorter path is preferred.

\#\#\# User: What should I do if somebody posts answer which is the same as (or very similar to) the one I posted? 

**Example:**

I wrote an answer: "Try following code: `<html>`". After one/two/... minutes, the other person posts the same answer, but in a little bit changed form, like: "That code might be helpful: `<html>`".

**Arghhh...**

That makes me irritated. Why? Because his answer is going on the top of the answers list and is earning reputation, and my answer, although it has been posted as the first and with the same meritorious content, is generally in a worse position...

**Conclusion**

What should I do? Flag it for moderator attention? I have done that, but I received this answer: *"declined \- flags should only be used to make moderators aware of content that requires their intervention."* Contact the author? Is that prohibited, in general? If not – I request to make that forbidden... 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you have compelling evidence that the post is plagiarizing your content, then you can say that, either through a moderator flag, or through the "contact us" link at the bottom of the page.

You should be describing, specifically, why you feel the post is copying your intellectual property.

Note that in many cases, when dealing with simple questions, different people can arrive at the same solution independently. This may well have been the case here. You should be providing evidence that it's either not possible, or extremely unlikely that this other user happened to provide this solution on their own.

22.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A user on a Q&A platform notices that another user has posted an answer very similar to theirs, shortly after they posted their own answer. What is the most appropriate initial action for the user to take in this situation?

A) Immediately flag the answer for moderator attention, citing plagiarism
B) Contact the other user directly and ask them to remove their answer
C) Evaluate the situation carefully and gather compelling evidence before taking any action
D) Edit their own answer to make it significantly different from the other user's answer

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most appropriate initial action is to carefully evaluate the situation and gather compelling evidence before taking any action. The documentation suggests that in many cases, especially for simple questions, different users can independently arrive at similar solutions. Before accusing someone of plagiarism or involving moderators, it's important to consider whether it's possible or likely that the other user came up with the solution on their own.

If after careful consideration, the user still believes there's a case for plagiarism, they should gather specific evidence demonstrating why it's unlikely or impossible for the other user to have arrived at the same solution independently. Only then should they consider flagging for moderator attention or using the "contact us" link, providing a detailed explanation of their concerns.

The other options are less appropriate:
A) is premature without careful evaluation and evidence.
B) direct contact to ask for removal could be seen as confrontational and is discouraged.
D) altering one's own correct answer is not a solution to the problem and could potentially reduce the quality of information available to other users.

\#\#\# User: I have some 20\+ year old garage door openers, and one works great, the other will sometimes open/close fine. 

Sometimes when I hit the switch there is a click and a buzz like the motor is trying to lift, but the door does not move. If I hit the switch again it stops. If I go over to the door and pull it up about an inch (or pull it down, if it's open) the motor "catches" and it goes up/down just fine.

Is there a slack adjustment of some sort I can look at, or is the motor bad? I replaced the capacitor on the door that is not working about 6 months ago, and have replaced the springs and safety cables on both doors at about the same time.

Any ideas?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Dry air is more dense than humid air, so your thinking about humid air accumulating near the ceiling makes sense. Because it's a basement, however, I'm going to assume humidity is coming through the floor or walls. Tackling the source of the humidity by letting drier air circulate along the floor and walls will probably be most effective at drying the space.

Your best bet may be to mount the fan as an intake on the bottom grate, so less humid air blows onto the floor and quickly disperses rising moisture. It would also help to open up some air space along the floor. You could achieve this by storing your items on a raised shelf or pallet. Providing this extra space for air circulation might even be enough to keep your storage room sufficiently dry without forced ventilation.

23.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In a basement storage room with high humidity, which of the following strategies would be LEAST effective in reducing moisture levels?

A) Installing a dehumidifier near the ceiling
B) Mounting a fan as an intake on the bottom grate to blow drier air onto the floor
C) Storing items on raised shelves or pallets to improve air circulation
D) Opening windows to allow for natural air exchange

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
A) Installing a dehumidifier near the ceiling would be the least effective strategy. The documentation suggests that in a basement, humidity is likely coming through the floor or walls. A dehumidifier placed near the ceiling would not effectively address the source of the moisture.

B) This is an effective strategy mentioned in the documentation. Mounting a fan as an intake on the bottom grate would help circulate drier air along the floor and walls, tackling the source of humidity.

C) This is also recommended in the documentation. Raising items off the floor creates space for air circulation, which can help keep the area dry.

D) While not explicitly mentioned in the documentation, opening windows for natural air exchange can be an effective way to reduce humidity, especially if the outside air is drier than the basement air.

The correct answer is A because it fails to address the primary source of humidity in a basement setting and would be less effective compared to the other options that focus on air circulation near the floor and walls.

\#\#\# User: As one becomes interested in statistics, the [dichotomy "Frequentist" vs. "Bayesian"](https://youtu.be/BOWNHl3qOVA) soon becomes commonplace (and who hasn't read [Nate Silver's *The Signal and the Noise*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Signal_and_the_Noise), anyway?). In talks and introductory courses, the point of view is overwhelmingly frequentist ([MLE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_likelihood), $p$ values), but there tends to be a tiny fraction of time dedicated to admire Bayes formula and touch upon the idea of a *prior distribution*, usually tangentially. 

The tone employed to discuss Bayesian statistics oscillates between respect for its conceptual underpinnings, and a hint of skepticism regarding the chasm between lofty objectives, and arbitrariness in the selection of the prior distribution, or eventual use of frequentist maths after all.

Sentences such as "if you are a hard\-core Bayesian..." abound.

The question is, Who are the Bayesians today? Are they some select academic institutions where you know that if you go there you will become a Bayesian? If so, are they specially sought after? Are we referring to just a few respected statisticians and mathematicians, and if so who are they?

Do they even exist as such, these pure "Bayesians"? Would they happily accept the label? Is it always a flattering distinction? Are they mathematicians with peculiar slides in meetings, deprived of any $p$ values and confidence intervals, easily spotted on the brochure?

How much of a [niche](https://normaldeviate.wordpress.com/2013/09/01/is-bayesian-inference-a-religion/) is being a "Bayesian"? Are we referring to a minority of statisticians?

Or is current Bayesian\-ism equated with machine learning applications?

... Or even more likely, is Bayesian statistics not so much a branch of statistics, but rather an [epistemological](http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/epistemology-bayesian/) movement that transcends the ambit of probability calculations into a philosophy of science? In this regard, all scientists would be Bayesian at heart... but there would be no such thing as a pure Bayesian statistician impermeable to frequentist techniques (or contradictions).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'm going to take your questions in order:

> The question is, Who are the Bayesians today?

Anybody who does Bayesian data analysis and self\-identifies as "Bayesian". Just like a programmer is someone who programs and self\-identifies as a "programmer". A slight difference is that for historical reasons *Bayesian* has ideological connotations, because of the often heated argument between proponents of "frequentist" interpretations of probability and proponents of "Bayesian" interpretations of probability.

> Are they some select academic institutions, where you know that if you go there you will become a Bayesian?

No, just like other parts of statistics you just need a good book (and perhaps a good teacher).

> If so, are they specially sought after?

Bayesian data analysis is a very useful tool when doing statistical modeling, which I imagine is a pretty sought\-after skill, (even if companies perhaps aren't specifically looking for "Bayesians").

> Are we referring to just a few respected statisticians and mathematicians, and if so who are they?

There are many respected statisticians that I believe would call themselves *Bayesians*, but those are not *the* Bayesians. 

> Do they even exist as such, these pure "Bayesians"?

That's a bit like asking "Do these pure programmers exist"? There is an amusing article called [46656 Varieties of Bayesians](http://fitelson.org/probability/good_bayes.pdf), and sure there is a healthy argument among "Bayesians" regarding many foundational issues. Just like programmers can argue over the merits of different programming techniques. (BTW, pure programmers program in Haskell).

> Would they happily accept the label?

Some do, some don't. When I discovered Bayesian data analysis I thought it was the best since sliced bread (I still do) and I was happy to call myself a "Bayesian" (not least to irritate the p\-value people at my department). Nowadays I don't like the term, I think it might alienate people as it makes Bayesian data analysis sound like some kind of cult, which it isn't, rather than a useful method to have in your statistical toolbox.

> Is it always a flattering distinction?

Nope! As far as I know, the term "Bayesian" was introduced by the famous statistician Fisher as a derogatory term. Before that it was called "inverse probability" or just "probability".

> Are they mathematicians with peculiar slides in meetings, deprived of any p values and confidence intervals, easily spotted on the brochure?

Well, there are conferences in Bayesian statistics, and I don't think they include that many p\-values. Whether you'll find the slides peculiar will depend on your background...

> How much of a niche is being a "Bayesian"? Are we referring to a minority of statisticians?

I still think a minority of statisticians deal with Bayesian statistics, but I also think the proportion is growing.

> Or is current Bayesian\-ism equated with machine learning applications?

Nope, but Bayesian models are used a lot in machine learning. Here is a great machine learning book that presents machine learning from a Bayesian/probibalistic perspective: [http://www.cs.ubc.ca/\~murphyk/MLbook/](http://www.cs.ubc.ca/~murphyk/MLbook/) 

Hope that answered most of the questions :)

*Update:*

> \[C]ould you please consider adding a list of specific techniques or premises that distinguish Bayesian statistics?

What distinguish Bayesian statistics is the use of Bayesian models :) Here is [my spin on what a Bayesian model *is*](https://stats.stackexchange.com/a/129712/6920):

*A Bayesian model is a statistical model where you use probability to represent all uncertainty within the model, both the uncertainty regarding the output but also the uncertainty regarding the input (aka parameters) to the model. The whole prior/posterior/Bayes theorem thing follows on this, but in my opinion, using probability for everything is what makes it Bayesian (and indeed a better word would perhaps just be something like probabilistic model).*

Now, Bayesian models can be tricky to *fit*, and there is a host of different computational techniques that are used for this. But these techniques are not *Bayesian* in themselves. To namedrop some computational techniques:

* Markov chain Monte Carlo
	+ Metropolis\-Hastings
	+ Gibbs sampling
	+ Hamiltonian Monte Carlo
* Variational Bayes
* Approximate Bayesian computation
* Particle filters
* Laplace approximation
* And so on...

> Who was the famous statistician who introduced the term 'Bayesian' as derogatory?

It was supposedly Ronald Fisher. The paper [When did Bayesian inference become "Bayesian"?](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ba/1340371071) gives the history of the term "Bayesian".

24.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Which of the following statements about Bayesian statistics is NOT accurate according to the information provided?

A) The term "Bayesian" was originally introduced as a derogatory term by statistician Ronald Fisher.

B) Bayesian models are characterized by using probability to represent all uncertainty within the model, including both input and output uncertainties.

C) Bayesian statistics is primarily equated with machine learning applications in modern times.

D) Computational techniques like Markov chain Monte Carlo and Variational Bayes are used to fit Bayesian models, but are not inherently Bayesian themselves.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The information provided states that Bayesian models are used a lot in machine learning, but Bayesian statistics is not equated with machine learning applications. The other statements are accurate based on the given information:

A is correct: The text mentions that "the term 'Bayesian' was introduced by the famous statistician Fisher as a derogatory term."

B is correct: The definition provided states that Bayesian models use "probability to represent all uncertainty within the model, both the uncertainty regarding the output but also the uncertainty regarding the input (aka parameters) to the model."

D is correct: The text lists various computational techniques used for fitting Bayesian models, but explicitly states "these techniques are not Bayesian in themselves."

C is the only statement that contradicts the information given, which states that Bayesian-ism is not equated with machine learning applications, even though Bayesian models are used extensively in machine learning.

\#\#\# User: I was playing a game over the weekend where you're allowed to give a one\-word clue. Someone said "RNA" and a disagreement followed as to whether or not it's a single word. At the time, we misidentified it as an acronym, but reading here I see that it's an initialism, which to my mind makes the difference.

Made me wonder the same thing about a hyphenated word \-\- "mother\-in\-law" seems like a good example. 

I know this is a silly question, but thoughts? 

Clarification: the main question at hand is, "is 'RNA' one word or three?"

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Initialisms and acronyms are words.

*RNA* is one word. It is not composed of the words "R", "N", and "A" because those individual words mean their respective letters, and *RNA*'s meaning is not its sequence of letters. It is certainly not composed of the words "ribonucleic" and "acid" because those words are neither written nor pronounced in *RNA* \-\- they're the *meaning* of the word *RNA*.

The creation of initialisms and acronyms is just another form of *blending*. If *smog* is one word, so is *RNA*.

25.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the linguistic status of initialisms and acronyms like "RNA"?

A) They are always considered multiple words, with each letter representing a separate word.
B) They are single words formed through a process similar to blending.
C) They are neither words nor multiple words, but a unique linguistic category.
D) Their word status depends on whether they can be pronounced as a single unit.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: According to the documentation, initialisms and acronyms like "RNA" are considered single words. They are formed through a process similar to blending, where multiple words are combined to create a new, single word. The meaning of "RNA" is not derived from its individual letters (R, N, and A) or the full words it represents (ribonucleic acid), but rather it has its own distinct meaning as a single unit. The comparison to "smog" (a blend of "smoke" and "fog") reinforces this concept. Therefore, "RNA" and similar initialisms or acronyms are linguistically treated as single words, making option B the correct answer.

\#\#\# User: I have an existing APC 1500 UPS, designed for use with 24v lead acid batteries and want to know if it would be possible to replace my dead lead acid battery with a 24V Lithium Iron Phosphate (LFP) battery instead. The 24V LFP battery comes with a built\-in BMS, so I assume (but don't know, not being a battery expert) that the BMS should be able to regulate and protect the LFP battery. I checked with the seller and they 'think' it should be possible but are not certain. Can anybody knowledgeable help?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I would say NO.
Yes 24 CFC is 24v and that would not matter but the charging circuitry for lithium ion is radically different than lead acid and using the APC battery charging circuit may cause the lithium ion battery to explode or catch fire.

If you can convert the charging circuit to a lithium ion type circuit then it could be possible.

27.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: An engineer is considering replacing a dead lead-acid battery in an APC 1500 UPS with a 24V Lithium Iron Phosphate (LFP) battery that has a built-in Battery Management System (BMS). Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this potential replacement?

A) The replacement is safe and straightforward because both batteries have the same voltage rating of 24V.

B) The replacement is possible only if the UPS's charging circuit is modified to be compatible with lithium-ion batteries.

C) The built-in BMS of the LFP battery will ensure safe charging, making the replacement feasible without any modifications.

D) The replacement is recommended by UPS manufacturers as a more efficient and longer-lasting alternative to lead-acid batteries.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. While both batteries have a 24V rating, the charging requirements for lead-acid and lithium-ion batteries are significantly different. The UPS's existing charging circuit is designed for lead-acid batteries and could potentially cause the lithium-ion battery to overheat, explode, or catch fire if used without modification. To safely use an LFP battery, the UPS's charging circuit would need to be converted to one compatible with lithium-ion batteries. 

Option A is incorrect because having the same voltage rating doesn't ensure compatibility or safety. 

Option C is incorrect because while the BMS can protect the battery itself, it cannot change the charging behavior of the UPS, which is the main concern.

Option D is incorrect as UPS manufacturers typically do not recommend such replacements due to the significant differences in charging requirements and potential safety hazards.

\#\#\# User: I'm using gsky wireless usb adapter model: Gsky\-link GS\-27USB.

When I connected it to a 15 meters usb extention cable it's recognized by the computer but it doesn't find any network.
Without the usb extention cable it finds many with good signal.

The cable I have seem to have a repeater (on one end it's pretty thick like the repeaters I see on these cables: [https://www.google.co.il/search?q\=usb\+repeater\&source\=lnms\&tbm\=isch\&sa\=X\&ved\=0ahUKEwjt\-L7a2MjQAhWhA8AKHWHaBd4Q\_AUICCgB\&biw\=1239\&bih\=627](https://www.google.co.il/search?q=usb+repeater&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjt-L7a2MjQAhWhA8AKHWHaBd4Q_AUICCgB&biw=1239&bih=627) )

Just as a test \- I replaced the original usb cable that connects the device to the computer with a simple cable and it also works.

Edit (added): The extention cable works when connected to a regular, simple disk\-on\-key.

Any suggestions?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There's probably a voltage drop and the USB adaptor isn't getting enough power. The solution would be to have a *powered* usb hub on the other end with the wireless adaptor.

If you wanted to see what the voltage/current was, and how your cable affects the power input to the adaptor you'd want a USB power meter of some flavour to check. I won't recommend any particular model, but there's quite a few generic models around for not much money for casual testing.

28.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A user is experiencing issues with a Gsky wireless USB adapter (model GS-27USB) when connected through a 15-meter USB extension cable. The adapter is recognized by the computer but cannot find any networks, despite working fine without the extension. What is the most likely cause of this problem and the recommended solution?

A) The USB extension cable is faulty and needs to be replaced with a higher quality cable.
B) The wireless adapter's drivers are incompatible with the USB extension cable and need to be updated.
C) There is a voltage drop due to the cable length, and a powered USB hub should be used at the end of the extension cable.
D) The wireless adapter's antenna is being interfered with by the extension cable, and a different adapter model should be used.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most likely cause of the problem is a voltage drop due to the length of the USB extension cable. USB cables have limitations on their length before signal degradation and voltage drop become significant issues. The wireless adapter is likely not receiving enough power to function correctly when connected through the long extension cable.

The recommended solution is to use a powered USB hub at the end of the extension cable. This will ensure that the wireless adapter receives sufficient power to operate correctly, even when connected through a long cable. This solution addresses the root cause of the problem without requiring changes to the adapter itself or its drivers.

Option A is incorrect because while cable quality can be a factor, the primary issue here is likely the cable length rather than its quality. Option B is unlikely since the adapter works fine without the extension. Option D is not the most probable cause, as USB cables typically don't interfere with wireless antennas to this extent.

\#\#\# Top Answer: **Setup upgrade:**

> php bin/magento s:up

**Cache Flush:**

> php bin/magento c:f

**Disable Cache:**

> php bin/magento c:d

**Enable Cache:**

> ​​​​​​php bin/magento c:e

**Static Content Deploy:**

> php bin/magento s:s:d

**Di Compile:**

> php bin/magento s:d:c

**Var clean folder:**

> php bin/magento v:c

**Uninstall Magento application:**

> php bin/magento s:un

**Runs cron job scheduled for setup application:**

> php bin/magento s:c:r

**Disables specified modules:**

> php bin/magento mo:d CompanyName\_ModuleName

**Enables specified modules:**

> php bin/magento mo:e CompanyName\_ModuleName

**Displays status of modules:**

> php bin/magento mo:s

**Uninstalls modules installed by composer (which only installed by composer):**

> php bin/magento mo:u CompanyName\_ModuleName

**Cleans cache type(s):**

> php bin/magento c:c

**Disables cache type(s):**

> php bin/magento c:d

**Enables cache type(s):**

> php bin/magento c:e

> php bin/magento c:s

> php bin/magento ma:d

**Shows allowed Indexers:**

> php bin/magento i:i

> php bin/magento i:res

> php bin/magento i:res

2. "php bin/magento s:s:d" deploys static content
3. "php bin/magento s:d:c" compiles dependency injection
4. "php bin/magento mo:e Acme_CustomModule" enables the specified module

Option B is incorrect because it uses "mo:d" which disables a module instead of enabling it.
Option C is incorrect as it starts with cache flush instead of setup upgrade and uses "mo:s" which only displays the status of modules.
Option D is incorrect because it begins with "s:un" which uninstalls the Magento application, and uses "mo:u" which uninstalls a module instead of enabling it.

\#\#\# User: I am running a Raspberry PI with Ubuntu 16\.04\.1 LTS (GNU/Linux 4\.4\.0\-1042\-raspi2 armv7l) and when I eg. watch a video via Samba, it gets cached and fills up my RAM with cached data.

This will look like this:

```
user@rpi:~$ free -h -m
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:           920M         57M        133M        980K        729M        828M
Swap:          1.8G         29M        1.8G

```

So as far as I understand this, it shouldn't be a bad thing since Ubuntu will see that part of RAM as used but available. So when another process actually needs it, it will be made available.

But when the cache reaches my RAM limit the following will happen:

```
Feb  8 19:08:36 rpi kernel: [160789.617128] Out of memory: Kill process 29171 (myprocess) score 40 or sacrifice child
Feb  8 19:06:08 rpi kernel: [160641.803753] Killed process 29072 (myprocess) total-vm:170312kB, anon-rss:63196kB, file-rss:43628kB

```

Can someone explain to me why this happens and how I can avoid this?
Right now my only temporary solution is to clear the cache manually:

```
sync && echo 3 > /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches

```

PS: I know I shouldn't use Swap on a RPI with a flash drive, it was a temporary test for this issue which didn't help.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [xcopy](https://ss64.com/nt/xcopy.html) appears to have been deprecated by MS. Theoretically, it should have copied the files *verbatim*, but has obviously failed, as shown by your careful comparison. Most video formats are somewhat fault\-tolerant, so are still viewable, but it does appear they have been damaged.

The issue might be the use of the /C, continue\-on\-error, option. With "healthy" media, there should be no errors. You might try using the /V option to verify files. If verification fails, then there is an issue such as bad media (e.g. a failing HDD or CD) or system noise. BTW, /J might be useful for large files, e.g. videos.
